inlineContent.text: This tutorial will guide you through building the documentation, documenting the symbols of a type, and adding images and asides to the documentation.
DocC documentation is built from your source code and optionally some Markdown files.
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
Select Product > Build Documentation in the menu bar.
You can also press ‚åÉ‚áß‚åòD to build the documentation.
A window containing the documentation should appear. Select BuildABuddyKit under ‚ÄúWorkspace Documentation‚Äù to view your documentation.

Spend a minute browsing the documentation. Notice that all the public types in the BuildABuddyKit package are included in the documentation but none of them are accomodated by text.  This documentation is similar to when Apple‚Äôs documentation shows ‚ÄúNo overview available‚Äù.
We have built the documentation but it is lacking descriptions of symbols, such as types, properties, and functions.
We can use a dialect of Markdown,
documentation markup
, to write our documentation. This dialect builds upon Markdown to add support for linking to symbols, asides, and much more.
When building the documentation, the DocC compiler converts the Markdown into rich documentation.
Do not worry. You will not have to document all types in BuildABuddyKit.
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
Select BuddyRenderer.swift in the Project navigator.
We will add documentation to the BuddyRenderer type. This type takes an instance of Buddy as input and outputs an image.
The first line in your documentation is treated as the summary which is shown below the type name. The summary should be kept short and concise. Add a summary to the documentation.
You are encouraged to build the documentation throughout each step of this series of tutorials. This will give you a better understanding of how the changes affect the documentation.
You can copy and paste the documentation from the source code on the right-hand side.
Add an overview to the type.
Lines following the summary is treated as the description. The overview can be long and detailed.
Notice that the overview contains backticks. The overview is written in Markdown and can contain code, links, images, tables, and lists. We will have a closer look at some of these later.
Replace `Buddy` with ``Buddy`` and `render(_:)` with ``render(_:)``. This will turn the type and function into links.
Double backticks (``) are used to refer to a symbol in the documentation. You can also use the alternative syntax
Add a code snippet showing users how to get started with the
Add a summary and a description to the two instance properties.
Place the cursor on top of the initializer. Then select Editor > Structure > Add Documentation. This will generate template documentation for the function.
You can also press ‚å•‚åò/ to add documentation.
After generating the documentation, you should be able to select the placeholders and fill out the summary and description of the parameters. See the next step for suggested texts.
Document the initializer by adding a summary and a description of the parameters.
Add documentation to the
function.
Finally, build the documentation and browse the documentation for
Checkout the
branch and build the documentation to view the documentation for all symbols.
We will add an image to the documentation of
to give adopters of the framework an idea of the output they can expect when calling

Images used in the documentation are stored inside a documentation catalog. The catalog is also used when enriching documentation in other wasy, such as when adding a landing page, structure, tutorials, and more.
We will look into other ways of enriching the documentation later in the tutorial but for now we will use the documentation catalog to store our image.
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
Start by adding the documentation catalog by right-clicking BuildABuddyKit in the Project navigator and selecting New File‚Ä¶
Choose Documentation Catalog in the Template picker and select Next.
You should see three new items in the Project navigator. There is the Documentation catalog which contains
and a folder named
. We will store our images in the
folder.
We will have a closer look at the
file in the
tutorial.
Download
and
These are the two images that we will add to the documentation. There is one image to be used in light mode and one to be used in dark mode.
Filenames of images that are intended for dark mode should be suffixed with
, for example
Drag the two downloaded images into the
folder in Xcode.
Select
in the Project navigator.
Add a short text informing users what the image depicts.
Add the image using Markdown syntax.
Notice that we are not explicitly specifying the image to be used in dark mode. DocC will automatically chose whether to use the light or dark variant based on the naming scheme.
Finally, build the documentation to view the image in the
type.
Checkout the
branch and build the documentation. Notice that the documentation now contains images for several types. For example, the documentation of each case in the
enum shows a preview of the shirt style.
Asides are used to get a reader‚Äôs attention and provide additional advice or warn about common errors and requisities.
In this section we will use asides to provide additional information about the usage of
Checkout the
branch in the Git repository.
Select
in the Project navigator.
Add an aside of type
to inform users about the default canvas size used by
and the benefits of using the default size.
Asides are created by starting a line with a greater-than symbol (
) followed by a space, the type of the aside, a colon (
), and the content of the aside. Valid types of asides are
, and
. Each type are stylized uniquely.
Add an aside of type
to warn users that creating a canvas with a negative size has undefined behavior.
Finally, build the documentation to view the asides in the
type.
How can you build and view the DocC documentation from Xcode?
Selecting View > Documentation in the menu bar.
Sorry, that is not correct.
Selecting Editor > View Documentation in the menu bar.
Oops, that is not correct.
Selecting Product > Build Documentation in the menu bar.
Correct! You can also press ‚åÉ‚áß‚åòD to build the documentation.
Which language do we use to write documentation when using DocC?
Markdown
That‚Äôs correct! We use a custom dialect of Markdown which includes features like symbol linking, asides, and much more.
HTML
Oops, that is not correct.
Swift
Sorry, that is not correct.
Can documentation of symbols contain syntax highlighted Swift code?
Yes, it can!
Correct! DocC documentation can contain syntax highlighted Swift code and it is a great way to get people quickly started using your types.
No, it cannot and that‚Äôs a bummer.
Sorry, that is not correct. Hint: The other option is correct üôä
Which of the following syntaxes can we use linking to the documentaton of the
type?
`BuddyRenderer`
Unfortunately, that was not correct.
``BuddyRenderer``
That‚Äôs correct! We can also use
to link to a symbol.
>BuddyRenderer<
Sorry, that is not correct.
Which of the following is a correct filename for an image that is used in dark mode?
hero@dark.png
Unfortunately, that was not correct.
hero-dark.png
Ouch! That was not correct.
hero~dark.png
Correct! DocC will automatically use images suffixed with
whemn viewing the documentation in darkmode.
Which of these is the correct syntax to use when adding an aside?

inlineContent.code: ! Warning: Build a Buddy is highly addictive.

inlineContent.text: Unfortunately, that was not correct.

inlineContent.code: > Warning: Build a Buddy is highly addictive.

inlineContent.text: That‚Äôs correct! An aside is created by typing a greater-than symbol (
) followed by a space, the type of the aside, a colon (
), and the content of the aside.

inlineContent.code: [Warning: Build a Buddy is highly addictive.]

inlineContent.text: Sorry, that is not correct.
Which types of asides provide a unique style when creting an aside?
Note, Important, Alert, Help, and Experiment.
Unfortunately, that was not correct.
Notice, Important, Warning, Hint, and Experiment.
Oops, that is not correct.
Note, Important, Warning, Tip, and Experiment.
That‚Äôs correct! You can create asides of any type but other types than those listed here will fallback to the appearance of the Note type.

abstract.text: In the previous section we learned how documentation can be written for types, properties, and functions. In this tutorial we will explore how we can add structure to our documentation.
This tuturial will guide you through downloading the example project and getting familiar with it.
Interactive tutorials are a great way to present your technology to readers.

content: /// Renders a buddy to an image.
/// The BuddyRenderer can be used to render an instance of ``Buddy`` into a UIImage. The appearance of the buddy should be configured before it is rendered.
/// Get started by creating an instance of `BuddyRenderer` by passing it a background color and a canvas size. Then call ``render(_:)`` and pass it an instance of ``Buddy`` to render an image.
public init(backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil, canvasSize: CGSize = CGSize(width: 600, height: 600)) {
public func render(_ buddy: Buddy) -> UIImage {
let scale = CGPoint(x: canvasSize.width / 600, y: canvasSize.height / 600)
let renderer = UIGraphicsImageRenderer(size: canvasSize, format: format)
// Rotate the image and then render the rotated image. This makes it easier to transfer values from Sketch to code.

content: /// Renders a buddy to an image.
/// The BuddyRenderer can be used to render an instance of ``Buddy`` into a UIImage. The appearance of the buddy should be configured before it is rendered.
/// Get started by creating an instance of `BuddyRenderer` by passing it a background color and a canvas size. Then call ``render(_:)`` and pass it an instance of ``Buddy`` to render an image.
/// The background color of the rendered image.
/// Set the background color to `nil` or `UIColor.clear` to render a transparent image. Defaults to `nil`.
/// The image returned by ``render(_:)`` will have this size.
/// Creates a `BuddyRenderer` given a background color and a canvas size.
///   - backgroundColor: The background color of the canvas. Defaults to `nil` for a transparent canvas.
///   - canvasSize: The size of the canvas. Defaults to 600 by 600.
public init(backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil, canvasSize: CGSize = CGSize(width: 600, height: 600)) {
/// Takes an instance of ``Buddy`` as input and renders it to the image. The size and background color of the image is specified by ``canvasSize`` and ``backgroundColor``.
/// - Parameter buddy: The buddy to render.
/// - Returns: A UIImage representation of the rendered image.
public func render(_ buddy: Buddy) -> UIImage {
let scale = CGPoint(x: canvasSize.width / 600, y: canvasSize.height / 600)
let renderer = UIGraphicsImageRenderer(size: canvasSize, format: format)
// Rotate the image and then render the rotated image. This makes it easier to transfer values from Sketch to code.

content: /// Renders a buddy to an image.

/// Get started by creating an instance of `BuddyRenderer` by passing it a background color and a canvas size. Then call ``render(_:)`` and pass it an instance of ``Buddy`` to render an image.
/// > Note: The default canvas size is 600 by 600. This canvas size provides for the best results.
/// Here's an image produced by an instance of `BuddyRenderer`:
/// > Warning: Providing a negative canvas size has undefined behavior.
/// The background color of the rendered image.
/// Set the background color to `nil` or `UIColor.clear` to render a transparent image. Defaults to `nil`.
/// The image returned by ``render(_:)`` will have this size.
/// Creates a `BuddyRenderer` given a background color and a canvas size.
///   - backgroundColor: The background color of the canvas. Defaults to `nil` for a transparent canvas.
///   - canvasSize: The size of the canvas. Defaults to 600 by 600.
public init(backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil, canvasSize: CGSize = CGSize(width: 600, height: 600)) {
/// Takes an instance of ``Buddy`` as input and renders it to the image. The size and background color of the image is specified by ``canvasSize`` and ``backgroundColor``.
/// - Parameter buddy: The buddy to render.
/// - Returns: A UIImage representation of the rendered image.
public func render(_ buddy: Buddy) -> UIImage {
let scale = CGPoint(x: canvasSize.width / 600, y: canvasSize.height / 600)
let renderer = UIGraphicsImageRenderer(size: canvasSize, format: format)
// Rotate the image and then render the rotated image. This makes it easier to transfer values from Sketch to code.

content: /// Renders a buddy to an image.
/// The BuddyRenderer can be used to render an instance of ``Buddy`` into a UIImage. The appearance of the buddy should be configured before it is rendered.
/// Get started by creating an instance of `BuddyRenderer` by passing it a background color and a canvas size. Then call ``render(_:)`` and pass it an instance of ``Buddy`` to render an image.
/// The background color of the rendered image.
/// Set the background color to `nil` or `UIColor.clear` to render a transparent image. Defaults to `nil`.
/// The image returned by ``render(_:)`` will have this size.
/// Creates a `BuddyRenderer` given a background color and a canvas size.
///   - backgroundColor: The background color of the canvas. Defaults to `nil` for a transparent canvas.
///   - canvasSize: The size of the canvas. Defaults to 600 by 600.
public init(backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil, canvasSize: CGSize = CGSize(width: 600, height: 600)) {
public func render(_ buddy: Buddy) -> UIImage {
let scale = CGPoint(x: canvasSize.width / 600, y: canvasSize.height / 600)
let renderer = UIGraphicsImageRenderer(size: canvasSize, format: format)
// Rotate the image and then render the rotated image. This makes it easier to transfer values from Sketch to code.
/// Renders a buddy to an image.
/// The BuddyRenderer can be used to render an instance of ``Buddy`` into a UIImage. The appearance of the buddy should be configured before it is rendered.
/// Get started by creating an instance of `BuddyRenderer` by passing it a background color and a canvas size. Then call ``render(_:)`` and pass it an instance of ``Buddy`` to render an image.
/// Here's an image produced by an instance of `BuddyRenderer`:
/// The background color of the rendered image.
/// Set the background color to `nil` or `UIColor.clear` to render a transparent image. Defaults to `nil`.
/// The image returned by ``render(_:)`` will have this size.
/// Creates a `BuddyRenderer` given a background color and a canvas size.
///   - backgroundColor: The background color of the canvas. Defaults to `nil` for a transparent canvas.
///   - canvasSize: The size of the canvas. Defaults to 600 by 600.
public init(backgroundColor: UIColor? = nil, canvasSize: CGSize = CGSize(width: 600, height: 600)) {
/// Takes an instance of ``Buddy`` as input and renders it to the image. The size and background color of the image is specified by ``canvasSize`` and ``backgroundColor``.
/// - Parameter buddy: The buddy to render.
/// - Returns: A UIImage representation of the rendered image.
public func render(_ buddy: Buddy) -> UIImage {
let scale = CGPoint(x: canvasSize.width / 600, y: canvasSize.height / 600)
let renderer = UIGraphicsImageRenderer(size: canvasSize, format: format)
// Rotate the image and then render the rotated image. This makes it easier to transfer values from Sketch to code.
